ai-sn36:1.3.2_0: and the path that leads to their ending.
ai-sn36:1.3.3_0: With the ending of feelings, a mendicant
ai-sn36:2.2.3_0: Those defilements that were found in me,
ai-sn36:2.3.3_0: experiencing what can be attained by one who sees these things.
ai-sn36:2.3.4_0: that’s how to be free of desire them.”
ai-sn36:3.1.4_0: The underlying tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency to repulsion should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The underlying tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling.
ai-sn36:3.1.5_0: When a mendicant has given up these underlying tendencies, they’re called a mendicant without underlying tendencies, who sees rightly, has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.
ai-sn36:3.2.3_0: the underlying tendency to greed is there,
ai-sn36:3.2.4_0: if you don’t see the escape.
ai-sn36:3.3.3_0: the underlying tendency to repulsion is there,
ai-sn36:3.3.4_0: if you don’t see the escape.
ai-sn36:3.4.1_0: As for that peaceful, neutral feeling:
ai-sn36:3.4.2_0: he of vast wisdom has taught
ai-sn36:3.4.3_0: If you take pleasure in it,
ai-sn36:3.4.4_0: you’re still not released from suffering.
ai-sn36:3.5.1_0: But when a mendicant is keen,
ai-sn36:3.6.2_0: they’re without defilements in this very life.
ai-sn36:3.6.3_0: When their body breaks up, after death,
ai-sn36:3.6.4_0: they use reckonings, but can’t be reckoned.”
ai-sn36:4.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when an uneducated ordinary person says that
ai-sn36:4.1.2_0: there is a time in the ocean.
ai-sn36:4.1.3_0: they’re speaking of something that doesn’t exist.
ai-sn36:4.1.4_0: there is a time in the ocean.
ai-sn36:4.1.5_0: ‘Hellish abyss’ is a term for painful physical feelings.
ai-sn36:4.1.6_0: When an uneducated ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-sn36:4.1.7_0: They’re called an uneducated ordinary person who hasn’t stood up in the hellish abyss and has gained no footing.
ai-sn36:4.1.8_0: When an educated noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-sn36:4.1.9_0: they’re called an educated noble disciple who gets up early and nose the tongue.
ai-sn36:4.2.4_0: if he is able to take it away.
ai-sn36:4.3.3_0: you would not stand up in the hellish abyss
ai-sn36:4.4.4_0: if you don’t tremble at their touch—
ai-sn36:4.4.5_0: you stand up in the hellish abyss
ai-sn36:4.4.6_0: and it will also be successful.”
ai-sn36:5.1.4_0: Pleasant feeling should be seen as suffering. Painful feeling should be seen as a dart. Neutral feeling should be seen as impermanent.
ai-sn36:5.1.5_0: When a mendicant has seen these three feelings in this way,
ai-sn36:5.1.6_0: they’re called a mendicant who has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.
ai-sn36:5.2.1_0: A mendicant who sees pleasure as pain,
ai-sn36:5.2.3_0: As for that peaceful, neutral feeling:
ai-sn36:5.3.4_0: they’re without defilements in this very life.
ai-sn36:5.3.5_0: When their body breaks up, after death,
ai-sn36:5.3.6_0: they use reckonings, but can’t be reckoned.”
ai-sn36:6.1.1_0: “Mendicants, an uneducated ordinary person feels pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.
ai-sn36:6.1.2_0: An educated noble disciple also feels pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.
ai-sn36:6.1.3_0: What, mendicants, is the difference between an educated noble disciple and an uneducated ordinary person?”
ai-sn36:6.1.4_0: we have been rooted in the Buddha. ...
ai-sn36:6.1.5_0: When an uneducated ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-sn36:6.1.8_0: Suppose a person was to pull arrow.
ai-sn36:6.1.9_0: but was struck with a second arrow.
ai-sn36:6.1.10_0: That person experiences the feeling of two arrows.
ai-sn36:6.1.11_0: In the same way, when an uneducated ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-sn36:6.1.14_0: When they’re touched by painful feeling, they resist it.
ai-sn36:6.1.15_0: The underlying tendency for repulsion towards painful feeling underlies that.
ai-sn36:6.1.16_0: When touched by painful feeling they look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures.
ai-sn36:6.1.18_0: Because an uneducated ordinary person doesn’t understand any escape from painful feeling apart from sensual pleasures.
ai-sn36:6.1.19_0: Since they look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures, the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling underlies that.
ai-sn36:6.1.20_0: They don’t truly understand feelings’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn36:6.1.21_0: The underlying tendency to ignorance about neutral feeling underlies that.
ai-sn36:6.1.22_0: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it attached.
ai-sn36:6.1.23_0: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it attached.
ai-sn36:6.1.24_0: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it attached.
ai-sn36:6.1.25_0: They’re called an uneducated ordinary person who is attached to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, I say.
ai-sn36:6.2.1_0: When an educated noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-sn36:6.3.1_0: Suppose a person was to pull arrow.
ai-sn36:6.3.2_0: but was not struck with a second arrow.
ai-sn36:6.3.3_0: That person would experience the feeling of one arrow.
ai-sn36:6.3.4_0: In the same way, when an educated noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-sn36:6.3.7_0: When they’re touched by painful feeling, they don’t resist it.
ai-sn36:6.3.8_0: There’s no underlying tendency for repulsion towards painful feeling underlying that.
ai-sn36:6.3.9_0: When touched by painful feeling they don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn36:6.3.11_0: Because an educated noble disciple understands an escape from painful feeling apart from sensual pleasures.
ai-sn36:6.3.12_0: Since they don’t look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures, there’s no underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling underlying that.
ai-sn36:6.3.13_0: They truly understand feelings’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn36:6.3.14_0: There’s no underlying tendency to ignorance about neutral feeling underlying that.
ai-sn36:6.3.15_0: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn36:6.3.16_0: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn36:6.3.17_0: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn36:6.3.18_0: They’re called an educated noble disciple who is detached from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, I say.
ai-sn36:6.3.19_0: This is the difference between an educated noble disciple and an uneducated ordinary person.
ai-sn36:6.4.1_0: A wise and learned person isn’t affected
ai-sn36:6.4.2_0: by feelings of pleasure and pain.
ai-sn36:6.4.3_0: This is the great difference in skill
ai-sn36:6.4.4_0: between the wise and the ordinary.
ai-sn36:6.5.1_0: A learned person who has appraised the teaching
ai-sn36:6.5.2_0: discerns this world and the next.
ai-sn36:6.5.4_0: nor are they repelled by the undesirable.
ai-sn36:6.6.2_0: are cleared and ended, they are no more.
ai-sn36:6.6.4_0: they understand rightly, going beyond rebirth.”
ai-sn36:6.6.5_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn36:7.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-sn36:7.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the infirmary, where
ai-sn36:7.1.2_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-sn36:7.2.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
ai-sn36:7.2.2_0: This is my instruction to you.
ai-sn36:7.3.1_0: And how is a mendicant mindful?
ai-sn36:7.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn36:7.3.4_0: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind ...
ai-sn36:7.3.5_0: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn36:7.3.6_0: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
ai-sn36:7.4.1_0: And how, monks, does a monk have full awareness?
ai-sn36:7.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
ai-sn36:7.4.3_0: That’s how a mendicant acts with situational awareness.
ai-sn36:7.4.4_0: A mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
ai-sn36:7.4.5_0: This is my instruction to you.
ai-sn36:7.5.1_0: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:
ai-sn36:7.5.2_0: ‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me.
ai-sn36:7.5.6_0: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
ai-sn36:7.5.7_0: So how could a pleasant feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’
ai-sn36:7.5.8_0: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and pleasant feeling.
ai-sn36:7.5.9_0: As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for greed for the body and pleasant feeling.
ai-sn36:7.6.1_0: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise, they understand:
ai-sn36:7.6.3_0: ‘A painful feeling has arisen in me.
ai-sn36:7.6.7_0: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
ai-sn36:7.6.8_0: So how could a painful feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’
ai-sn36:7.6.9_0: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and painful feeling.
ai-sn36:7.6.10_0: As they do so, they meditate observing impermanence in the body and painful feeling. ...
ai-sn36:7.6.10_1: When you meditate observing an aspect of the body and painful feeling,
ai-sn36:7.7.1_0: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:
ai-sn36:7.7.2_0: ‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me.
ai-sn36:7.7.6_0: But this body is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
ai-sn36:7.7.7_0: So how could a neutral feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’
ai-sn36:7.7.8_0: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and neutral feeling.
ai-sn36:7.7.9_0: As they do so, they meditate observing impermanence in the body and neutral feeling. ...
ai-sn36:7.7.9_1: When you meditate observing an aspect of the body and neutral feeling, the underlying tendency for ignorance is given up and ignorance.
ai-sn36:7.8.1_0: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn36:7.8.2_0: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn36:7.8.3_0: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn36:7.8.4_0: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn36:7.8.5_0: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn36:7.8.6_0: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn36:7.8.7_0: Feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’
ai-sn36:7.8.8_0: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’
ai-sn36:7.9.1_0: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.
ai-sn36:7.9.2_0: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.
ai-sn36:7.9.3_0: In the same way, feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’
ai-sn36:7.9.3_1: Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’
ai-sn36:7.9.4_0: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”
ai-sn36:8.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-sn36:8.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the infirmary, where
ai-sn36:8.1.2_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-sn36:8.2.1_0: “Mendicants, a mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
ai-sn36:8.2.2_0: This is my instruction to you.
ai-sn36:8.3.1_0: And how is a mendicant mindful?
ai-sn36:8.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn36:8.3.4_0: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind ...
ai-sn36:8.3.5_0: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn36:8.3.6_0: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
ai-sn36:8.4.1_0: And how, monks, does a monk have full awareness?
ai-sn36:8.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
ai-sn36:8.4.2_1: and in maintaining silence, he is one who practises with full awareness.
ai-sn36:8.4.3_0: Thus, monks, a monk has full awareness.
ai-sn36:8.4.4_0: A mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
ai-sn36:8.4.5_0: This is my instruction to you.
ai-sn36:8.5.1_0: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:
ai-sn36:8.5.3_0: ‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me.
ai-sn36:8.5.7_0: But this contact is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.
ai-sn36:8.5.8_0: So how could a pleasant feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on contact that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’
ai-sn36:8.5.9_0: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in contact and pleasant feeling.
ai-sn36:8.5.10_0: As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for greed for pleasant feeling.
ai-sn36:8.6.1_0: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise ...
ai-sn36:8.6.3_0: if neutral feelings arise, they understand:
ai-sn36:8.6.5_0: ‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me.
ai-sn36:8.6.9_0: (Expand in detail as in the previous discourse.)
ai-sn36:8.6.10_0: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’
ai-sn36:8.7.1_0: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.
ai-sn36:8.7.2_0: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.
ai-sn36:8.7.3_0: In the same way, feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’
ai-sn36:8.7.3_1: Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’
ai-sn36:8.7.4_0: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”
ai-sn36:9.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these three feelings are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.
ai-sn36:9.1.4_0: These are the three feelings that are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.”
ai-sn36:10.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these three feelings are born, rooted, sourced, and conditioned by contact.
ai-sn36:10.1.4_0: Pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn36:10.1.5_0: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.
ai-sn36:10.1.6_0: Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn36:10.1.7_0: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.
ai-sn36:10.1.8_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn36:10.1.9_0: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.
ai-sn36:10.1.10_0: When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced.
ai-sn36:10.1.10_1: But when these places are faded away and ceased, the corresponding heat ceases and stops.
ai-sn36:10.1.11_0: In the same way, these three feelings are born, rooted, sourced, and conditioned by contact.
ai-sn36:10.1.12_0: The appropriate feeling arises dependent on the corresponding contact.
ai-sn36:10.1.13_0: When the corresponding contact ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”
ai-sn36:10.1.15_0: The first sub-chapter on feeling is finished.
ai-sn36:10.2.1_0: with the giving up of immersion
ai-sn36:11.1.1_0: Then a certain monk went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn36:11.1.2_0: “Just now, Sir, while I was in seclusion, I thought,
ai-sn36:11.1.3_0: The Buddha has spoken of three feelings.
ai-sn36:11.1.5_0: These are the three feelings the Buddha has spoken of.
ai-sn36:11.1.8_0: What was this spoken by the Fortunate One
ai-sn36:11.2.2_0: I have spoken of these three feelings.
ai-sn36:11.2.4_0: These are the three feelings I have spoken of.
ai-sn36:11.2.7_0: When I said this I was referring to the impermanence of conditions, to the fact that conditions are
ai-sn36:11.2.13_0: if they live according to the Teaching,
ai-sn36:11.2.15_0: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of conditions.
ai-sn36:11.2.16_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.17_0: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.18_0: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.19_0: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.20_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.21_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.22_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.23_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.24_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.25_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have ceased.
ai-sn36:11.2.26_0: Then I have explained the progressive cessation of conditions.
ai-sn36:11.2.27_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has stilled.
ai-sn36:11.2.28_0: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have stilled. ...
ai-sn36:11.2.29_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have stilled.
ai-sn36:11.2.30_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have stilled.
ai-sn36:11.2.31_0: There are these six levels of tranquility.
ai-sn36:11.2.32_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:11.2.33_0: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:11.2.34_0: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:11.2.35_0: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:11.2.36_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:11.2.37_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”
ai-sn36:12.1.1_0: “Mendicants, various winds blow in the sky.
ai-sn36:12.1.2_0: Winds blow from the east, the west, the north, and the south. There are winds that are dusty and dustless, cool and warm, weak and strong.
ai-sn36:12.1.3_0: In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.
ai-sn36:12.2.2_0: winds that blow in the sky.
ai-sn36:12.2.3_0: From the east they come, also the west,
ai-sn36:12.2.4_0: the north, and then the south.
ai-sn36:12.3.4_0: the winds blow in the sky.
ai-sn36:12.5.1_0: But when a mendicant is keen,
ai-sn36:12.6.2_0: they’re without defilements in this very life.
ai-sn36:12.6.3_0: When their body breaks up, after death,
ai-sn36:12.6.4_0: they use reckonings, but can’t be reckoned.”
ai-sn36:13.1.1_0: “Mendicants, various winds blow in the sky.
ai-sn36:13.1.2_0: Winds blow from the east, the west, the north, and the south. There are winds that are dusty and dustless, cool and warm, weak and strong.
ai-sn36:13.1.3_0: In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.”
ai-sn36:14.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose there was a guest house.
ai-sn36:14.1.1_1: Lodgers come from the east, west, north, and south.
ai-sn36:14.1.1_2: Aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers all stay there.
ai-sn36:14.1.2_0: so too, monks, for this body arises
ai-sn36:14.1.3_0: Also material pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings arise.
ai-sn36:14.1.4_0: Also spiritual pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings arise.”
ai-sn36:15.1.1_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn36:15.1.1_1: After going, he sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:
ai-sn36:15.1.2_0: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?
ai-sn36:15.1.3_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”
ai-sn36:15.1.7_0: Contact is the origin of contact.
ai-sn36:15.1.9_0: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-sn36:15.1.11_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling ...
ai-sn36:15.1.12_0: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn36:15.1.13_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.
ai-sn36:15.1.14_0: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of conditions.
ai-sn36:15.1.15_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has ceased. ...
ai-sn36:15.1.16_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
ai-sn36:15.1.17_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have ceased.
ai-sn36:15.1.18_0: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of conditions.
ai-sn36:15.1.19_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has stilled. ...
ai-sn36:15.1.20_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have stilled.
ai-sn36:15.1.21_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have stilled.
ai-sn36:15.1.22_0: But I have also explained the progressive teaching.
ai-sn36:15.1.23_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has been tranquilized. ...
ai-sn36:15.1.24_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:15.1.25_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:15.1.26_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:15.1.27_0: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:15.1.28_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:15.1.29_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”
ai-sn36:16.1.1_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn36:16.1.2_0: “Ānanda, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?
ai-sn36:16.1.3_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”
ai-sn36:16.1.4_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha.
ai-sn36:16.1.4_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn36:16.1.4_2: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn36:16.1.5_0: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn36:16.1.12_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”
ai-sn36:16.1.13_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn36:17.1.1_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn36:17.1.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn36:17.1.2_0: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?
ai-sn36:17.1.3_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”
ai-sn36:17.1.7_0: Contact is the origin of contact.
ai-sn36:17.1.9_0: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-sn36:17.1.11_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling ...
ai-sn36:17.1.12_0: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn36:17.1.13_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.
ai-sn36:17.2.1_0: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of conditions.
ai-sn36:17.2.2_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has ceased. ...
ai-sn36:17.2.3_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have ceased.
ai-sn36:17.2.4_0: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of conditions.
ai-sn36:17.2.5_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has stilled. ...
ai-sn36:17.2.6_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have stilled.
ai-sn36:17.2.8_0: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:17.2.9_0: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:17.2.10_0: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:17.2.11_0: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:17.2.12_0: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have been tranquilized.
ai-sn36:17.2.13_0: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”
ai-sn36:18.1.1_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn36:18.1.3_0: “Mendicants, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?
ai-sn36:18.1.4_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”
ai-sn36:18.1.5_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn36:18.1.9_0: (This should be told in full as in the previous discourse.)
ai-sn36:19.1.1_0: Then the master builder Pañcakaṅga went to Udāyī
ai-sn36:19.1.1_1: bowed, sat down to one side,
ai-sn36:19.1.1_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and asked Udāyī,
ai-sn36:19.1.2_0: “Sir, how many feelings has the Buddha spoken of?”
ai-sn36:19.1.3_0: “Master builder, the Buddha has spoken of three feelings:
ai-sn36:19.1.5_0: The Buddha has spoken of these three feelings.”
ai-sn36:19.1.6_0: When he said this, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,
ai-sn36:19.1.7_0: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings,
ai-sn36:19.1.10_0: The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”
ai-sn36:19.2.1_0: For a second time, Udāyī said to him,
ai-sn36:19.2.2_0: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings,
ai-sn36:19.2.3_0: The Buddha has spoken of three feelings.
ai-sn36:19.2.5_0: These are the three feelings the Buddha has spoken of.”
ai-sn36:19.2.6_0: For a second time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,
ai-sn36:19.2.7_0: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings,
ai-sn36:19.2.10_0: The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”
ai-sn36:19.3.1_0: And for a third time, Udāyī said to him,
ai-sn36:19.3.2_0: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of two feelings,
ai-sn36:19.3.3_0: The Buddha has spoken of three feelings.
ai-sn36:19.3.5_0: These are the three feelings the Buddha has spoken of.”
ai-sn36:19.3.6_0: And for a third time, Pañcakaṅga said to Udāyī,
ai-sn36:19.3.7_0: “The Buddha hasn’t spoken of three feelings,
ai-sn36:19.3.10_0: The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”
ai-sn36:19.3.11_0: But neither was able to persuade the other.
ai-sn36:19.3.12_0: Venerable Ānanda heard this discussion between Udāyī and Pañcakaṅga.
ai-sn36:19.4.1_0: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
ai-sn36:19.4.2_0: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
ai-sn36:19.5.1_0: “Ānanda, the explanation by the mendicant Udāyī, which the master builder Pañcakaṅga didn’t agree with,
ai-sn36:19.5.2_0: But the explanation by Pañcakaṅga, which Udāyī didn’t agree with, was also quite correct.
ai-sn36:19.5.3_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.
ai-sn36:19.5.4_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings.
ai-sn36:19.5.5_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of the five feelings.
ai-sn36:19.5.6_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of six.
ai-sn36:19.5.7_0: In one eighteen feelings I have spoken of.
ai-sn36:19.5.8_0: Also he has spoken of six feelings,
ai-sn36:19.5.9_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of eight feelings.
ai-sn36:19.5.10_0: I’ve taught the Dhamma with all these explanations.
ai-sn36:19.5.11_0: This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will argue, quarrel, and fight, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
ai-sn36:19.5.12_0: I’ve taught the Dhamma with all these explanations.
ai-sn36:19.5.13_0: This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
ai-sn36:19.6.1_0: Ānanda, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-sn36:19.6.3_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. ...
ai-sn36:19.6.4_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn36:19.6.5_0: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-sn36:19.6.6_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure.
ai-sn36:19.6.8_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.6.9_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.6.12_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.7.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.7.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn36:19.7.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.7.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.7.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.7.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.8.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.8.2_0: It’s when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn36:19.8.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.8.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.8.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.8.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.9.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.9.2_0: It’s when, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare:
ai-sn36:19.9.2_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
ai-sn36:19.9.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.9.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.9.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.9.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.10.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.10.2_0: It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-sn36:19.10.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.10.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.10.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.10.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.11.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.11.2_0: It’s when a mendicant—going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity—aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
ai-sn36:19.11.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.11.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.11.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.11.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.12.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.12.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
ai-sn36:19.12.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.12.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.12.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.12.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.13.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.13.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
ai-sn36:19.13.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.13.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.13.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.13.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.14.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.14.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-sn36:19.14.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.14.4_0: There are those who would say
ai-sn36:19.14.5_0: that this is the highest pleasure and happiness that sentient beings experience.
ai-sn36:19.14.8_0: Because there is another pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.15.1_0: And what is that pleasure that is finer than that?
ai-sn36:19.15.2_0: It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling.
ai-sn36:19.15.3_0: This is a pleasure that is finer than that.
ai-sn36:19.16.1_0: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,
ai-sn36:19.16.2_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama spoke of the cessation of perception and feeling, and he includes it in happiness.
ai-sn36:19.16.4_0: When wanderers who follow other paths say this, you should say to them,
ai-sn36:19.16.5_0: ‘Reverends, when the Buddha describes what’s included in happiness, he’s not just referring to pleasant feeling.
ai-sn36:19.16.6_0: The Realized One describes pleasure as included in happiness wherever it’s found, and in whatever context.’”
ai-sn36:20.1.1_0: “Mendicants, in one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.
ai-sn36:20.1.2_0: I’ve taught the Dhamma with all these explanations.
ai-sn36:20.1.3_0: This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will argue, quarrel, and fight, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
ai-sn36:20.1.4_0: I’ve taught the Dhamma with all these explanations.
ai-sn36:20.1.5_0: This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
ai-sn36:20.2.1_0: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation. ...
ai-sn36:20.2.2_0: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say:
ai-sn36:20.2.3_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama spoke of the cessation of perception and feeling, and he includes it in happiness.
ai-sn36:20.2.5_0: Mendicants, when wanderers who follow other paths say this, you should say to them:
ai-sn36:20.2.6_0: ‘Reverends, when the Buddha describes what’s included in happiness, he’s not just referring to pleasant feeling.
ai-sn36:20.2.7_0: The Realized One describes pleasure as included in happiness wherever it’s found, and in whatever context.’”
ai-sn36:20.2.9_0: The second sub-chapter on private is finished.
ai-sn36:20.3.4_0: A mendicant who has five factors:
ai-sn36:21.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn36:21.1.2_0: Then the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka went up to the Buddha.
ai-sn36:21.1.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn36:21.1.3_1: He asked the Buddha the same questions, and received the same answers.
ai-sn36:21.1.4_0: “Master Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
ai-sn36:21.1.5_0: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’
ai-sn36:21.1.6_0: What do you say about this?”
ai-sn36:21.2.1_0: “Sīvaka, some feelings stem from bile disorders.
ai-sn36:21.2.2_0: You can know this from your own personal experience,
ai-sn36:21.2.3_0: and it is generally agreed to be true.
ai-sn36:21.2.4_0: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that
ai-sn36:21.2.5_0: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’
ai-sn36:21.2.6_0: And that’s what they meant and pass away from the world, and they agree with me.
ai-sn36:21.2.7_0: So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.
ai-sn36:21.3.1_0: Some feelings stem from phlegm disorders ...
ai-sn36:21.3.7_0: Some feelings are the result of past deeds.
ai-sn36:21.3.8_0: You can know this from your own personal experience,
ai-sn36:21.3.9_0: and so some feelings are the result of past deeds.
ai-sn36:21.3.10_0: and it is generally agreed to be true.
ai-sn36:21.3.11_0: and so some feelings are the result of past deeds.
ai-sn36:21.3.12_0: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that
ai-sn36:21.3.13_0: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’
ai-sn36:21.3.14_0: And that’s what they meant and pass away from the world, and they agree with me.
ai-sn36:21.3.15_0: So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.”
ai-sn36:21.4.1_0: When he said this, the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka said to the Buddha,
ai-sn36:21.4.3_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-sn36:21.5.3_0: not taking care of yourself, overexertion,
ai-sn36:22.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching on the hundred and eight.
ai-sn36:22.1.3_0: And what is the exposition of the teaching on the hundred and eight?
ai-sn36:22.1.4_0: Mendicants, in one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.
ai-sn36:22.1.5_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings.
ai-sn36:22.1.6_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of the five feelings.
ai-sn36:22.1.7_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of six.
ai-sn36:22.1.8_0: In one eighteen feelings I have spoken of.
ai-sn36:22.1.9_0: Also he has spoken of six feelings,
ai-sn36:22.1.10_0: In one explanation I’ve spoken of eight feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.1_0: And what are the two feelings?
ai-sn36:22.2.3_0: These are called the two feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.4_0: And what are the three feelings?
ai-sn36:22.2.6_0: These are called the three feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.7_0: And what are the five feelings?
ai-sn36:22.2.8_0: The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.
ai-sn36:22.2.9_0: These are called the five feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.10_0: And what are the six feelings?
ai-sn36:22.2.13_0: These are called the six feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.14_0: And what are the eighteen feelings?
ai-sn36:22.2.15_0: There are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity. ...
ai-sn36:22.2.16_0: These are called the eighteen feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.17_0: And what are the thirty-six feelings?
ai-sn36:22.2.18_0: Six kinds of lay happiness and six kinds of renunciate happiness. Six kinds of lay sadness and six kinds of renunciate sadness. Six kinds of lay equanimity and six kinds of renunciate equanimity. ...
ai-sn36:22.2.19_0: These are called the thirty-six feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.20_0: And what are the hundred and eight feelings?
ai-sn36:22.2.21_0: Thirty six feelings in the past, future, and present.
ai-sn36:22.2.22_0: These are called the hundred and eight feelings.
ai-sn36:22.2.23_0: This is the exposition of the teaching on the hundred and eight.”
ai-sn36:23.1.1_0: Then a certain monk went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn36:23.1.2_0: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the origin of feeling?
ai-sn36:23.1.3_0: What is feeling? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
ai-sn36:23.1.4_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”
ai-sn36:23.2.4_0: Contact is the origin of contact.
ai-sn36:23.2.5_0: Craving is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling.
ai-sn36:23.2.7_0: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-sn36:23.2.9_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling ...
ai-sn36:23.2.10_0: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-sn36:23.2.11_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.”
ai-sn36:24.1.1_0: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
ai-sn36:24.1.2_0: ‘What is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?
ai-sn36:24.1.3_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?’
ai-sn36:24.1.8_0: Contact is the origin of contact.
ai-sn36:24.1.9_0: Craving is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling ...
ai-sn36:24.1.10_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.’”
ai-sn36:25.1.1_0: “‘These feelings are feelings’: vision arose in me, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, and light arose, in regard to things not heard before.
ai-sn36:25.1.3_0: ‘This is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling.’ ...
ai-sn36:25.1.5_0: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling.’ ...
ai-sn36:25.1.8_0: ‘This is the escape from feeling.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.”
ai-sn36:26.1.1_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn36:26.1.1_1: and after approaching they’re headed for the full ordination.
ai-sn36:26.1.2_0: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the origin of feeling?
ai-sn36:26.1.3_0: What is feeling? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation?
ai-sn36:26.1.4_0: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”
ai-sn36:26.1.8_0: Contact is the origin of contact.
ai-sn36:26.1.9_0: Craving is the practice that leads to the origin of feeling.
ai-sn36:26.1.11_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.”
ai-sn36:26.1.12_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn36:27.1.4_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these three feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn36:27.1.5_0: I don’t regard them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.
ai-sn36:27.1.6_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these three feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn36:27.1.7_0: I regard them as true ascetics and brahmins.
ai-sn36:27.1.7_1: Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”
ai-sn36:28.1.4_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these three feelings’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape. ...
ai-sn36:28.1.5_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand ...”
ai-sn36:29.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand feeling, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. ...
ai-sn36:29.1.2_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand ...”
ai-sn36:31.1.1_0: “There is material rapture, spiritual rapture, and spiritual rapture.
ai-sn36:31.1.2_0: There is material pleasure, spiritual pleasure, and even more spiritual pleasure.
ai-sn36:31.1.3_0: There is material equanimity, spiritual equanimity, and even more spiritual equanimity.
ai-sn36:31.1.4_0: There is material liberation, spiritual liberation, and even more spiritual liberation.
ai-sn36:31.1.6_0: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-sn36:31.1.8_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. ...
ai-sn36:31.1.9_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn36:31.1.10_0: these, monks, are the five strands of sense pleasure.
ai-sn36:31.1.11_0: The rapture that arises from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called material rapture.
ai-sn36:31.2.2_0: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn36:31.2.3_0: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption ...
ai-sn36:31.3.1_0: And what is even more spiritual rapture?
ai-sn36:31.3.2_0: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, rapture arises. This is called even more spiritual rapture.
ai-sn36:31.4.2_0: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-sn36:31.4.4_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. ...
ai-sn36:31.4.5_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn36:31.4.6_0: these, monks, are the five strands of sense pleasure.
ai-sn36:31.4.7_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called material pleasure.
ai-sn36:31.5.2_0: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn36:31.5.3_0: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption ...
ai-sn36:31.5.4_0: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
ai-sn36:31.5.4_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
ai-sn36:31.6.1_0: And what is even more spiritual pleasure?
ai-sn36:31.6.2_0: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, pleasure and happiness arises. This is called even more spiritual pleasure.
ai-sn36:31.7.2_0: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-sn36:31.7.4_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. ...
ai-sn36:31.7.5_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn36:31.7.6_0: these, monks, are the five strands of sense pleasure.
ai-sn36:31.7.7_0: The equanimity that arises from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called material equanimity.
ai-sn36:31.8.2_0: It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-sn36:31.9.1_0: And what is even more spiritual equanimity?
ai-sn36:31.9.2_0: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, pleasure and equanimity. This is called even more spiritual equanimity.
ai-sn36:31.10.2_0: Liberation connected with form is material.
ai-sn36:31.11.2_0: Liberation connected with the formless is spiritual.
ai-sn36:31.12.1_0: And what is even more spiritual liberation?
ai-sn36:31.12.2_0: When a mendicant who has ended the defilements reviews their mind free from greed, hate, and delusion, is called even more spiritual liberation.”
ai-sn36:31.12.4_0: The third sub-chapter on eight hundred is finished.
ai-sn36:31.13.1_0: a mendicant who has eight years of seniority.
ai-sn36:31.13.5_0: The Linked Discourses on feeling are complete.
